Topic.Title: Cnbc breaks accounting fraud at Apple. Analyst says earnings a bogus

Message.Msg: Right, that was my point too. What B.J. Bethany from GS is saying is that the earnings aren't the real earnings. That if you normalize them to some other earnings, lets say earnings that are substantially lower, then apples profits will be greatly reduced and the seemingly low P/E today won't seem so low anymore. In addition to lowering their earnings, say by 50% which is more normalized, she talks about how the company could start burning through cash, presumably when the normalized earnings go negative. Then, when the normalized earnings are negative, you'll realize that the 137 billion in cash really isn't 137 billion in cash because they'll have to use that to support the negative earning operation. It's classic Enron style accounting fraud. The same fraud that all the major banks helped Enron to perpetrate. That they all then kept quit about until B.J. Bethany and pock face Chanos came along and just so happened to discover the fraud that all the major banks were already aware of because they set it up for Andrew Fastcar. Like I said in another post, it's like Christopher Columbus discovering America except have the Vikings tell Columbus that the new world is across the ocean we know this because we've been there. Get it. So really if you turn earnings negative for Apple, then you can now clearly see why it is only worth 200 dollars per share. Simple math. Classic accounting Fraud. It's not obvious to you now because they are making so much cash earnings, but later this year when the earnings get normalized to negative, then you'll be able to understand why the P/E was deceptive.

Message.Title: Maclean Gave No Apple Specific Facts, But Here Is Definition of "Normalized Earnings"...
Message.Msg: Normalized Earnings 1. Earnings for a company not including nonrecurring charges and gains. A one-time charge or gain that deeply affects a company's profits or losses for a given period of time might make it appear more or less healthy than it really is; normalized earnings are an indication of a company's true financial health. 2. Earnings that account for seasonal or economic cycles. See also: Seasonally-adjusted. normalized earnings Past or forecasted earnings that have been adjusted for cyclical variations. Earnings are generally normalized by using a moving average of earnings per share over a number of successive periods. Base speculations aired without aggressive questioning: thy name is CNBC/ MELISSA LEE/FAST MONEY/OPENING BELL, etc...

Topic.Title: DOJ investigating John Melloy & Steph Landsman producer CNBC

Message.Msg: The most recent market manipulation was documented and included in our data is from 02/06/2013 and 02/07/2013 . In each instance a guest "analyst was given a few moments of air time to manipulate the stock of Apple Computer of Curpertino Calif. The guest speaker was asked to broadcast his analysis of this high beta stock. While he was speaking ,,the stock fluctuated with every negative word he uttered. The 02/07/2013 event was on the CNBC show "FAST MONEY" and the female so-called "Apple expert" with no credentials for voicing an expert analysis , advised that Apple Computer ( a current ~$450B-~$650 valuation company with ~$135B cash and no debt ) was worth $200B. At that time after hours and on the date of record for the dividend, the stock fell as she spoke. This caused panic with retail investors (relying on so-called experts) and consequentially sold after hours, and in so doing will not be entitled to the quarterly dividend. This current act of market manipulation will be strengthened tomorrow when the stock of Apple Computer trades well above this manipulated price. Let us be clear and succinct: WI have personally documented these events many hundreds of times over throughout the past 5 years. Documented facts of these correlations and have interviewed many people hurt by the actions of these individuals and Entities delivering less than truthful information and/or speaking as an analyst , when indeed they do not qualify. For the case with Apple Computer we have well respected and highly regarded Gene Munster who has a target 400%+ higher than the guest who spoke 02/06/2013 on CNBC. Gene Munster has been covering and studying Apple Computer for many years. His analysis (although sometimes untimely due to broad market anomalies) has been at worst prescient to "spot on". This display 02/06/2013 with a random guest really was quite a disgust to all who witnessed it. CNBC you do need to explain at some point.

Topic.Title: Maclean Gave No Apple Specific Facts, But Here Is Definition of "Normalized Earnings"...

Message.Msg: Exactly. Apple's earnings were, and are, much higher than they used to be. There is no evidence that they will retreat to levels of, say, 2002 to 2006. A growth company grows, and a normalization curve follows the earnings arc up, as in Apple's case or down, as could be the case, although the down at this point in time appears fairly minimal, as profit of a billion dollars a week or a bit less is a lot of profit. Maclean reference to normalized earnings was just a reference to accounting basics that pose no threat to Apple at this time. Apple is still Apple, balls or not, and billions of profit/FCF/divys, is what you buy for your share purchase today, and your confidence in that state continuing or growing in the future. Maclean was perhaps the lousiest hack job on CNBC I have ever seen, and that is a high bar to hurdle. Shameful empty slander and supposition.

Topic.Title: Cnbc breaks accounting fraud at Apple. Analyst says earnings a bogus

Message.Msg: Now, correct me if i'm wrong, but i read through the article. i didn't see you say $200 a share, though, that was in the headline. do you think 200 is the right number? how do you get there? i don't think 200 is necessarily the right number. what the article says is, is apple a value trap? and i think the idea is, it might have farther to fall. just because it was once $700 a share doesn't give any reason that it should be $700 a share again. and it seems like, you know, you lay out a lot of the case that the bears will throw out, that it's momentum its slowing, that its share is decreasing, but a lot of the argument has to do with stock psychology and how so many analysts were just willing to give it a pass. do you think that is what had kept apple going higher and now is responsible for the fall? i think there's some of that, yeah. i think psychology is a really powerful thing. it's human nature to think that there's a reason it should be at $700 a share again. but there's this argument, if you think about value investor, they look at normalized earning, and there's this argument that apple's earnings of the past couple of years, which make its stock look so cheap weren't real. they were this extraordinary thing. and that apple's true level of earnings is something much lower, making it more expensive stock that it might appear, by the p.e. measure. bethany, it's karen. let me ask you. how do you think about -- i know $200 isn't the valu assigned, but given what you're saying about potential slowdown and loss of market share and ing -- earning less what the street thinks, what is the rice price for apple at this point? i have heard people toss levels around $200, the apple skeptics out there. the huge amount of cash apple has, tax adjusted, $111 a share right now, so, you'd say it's hard to believe it's going to go to that level, until they show signs of starting to burn through cash. if they do. there's an aument that technology companies once innovation dries up

Message.Title: Apple Acquires Polar Rose a facial-recognition company
Message.Msg: Apple has acquired Malmo, Sweden-based Polar Rose, a facial-recognition company with several products that could be integrated into Apple's current and future product lines, CNET News reports. Polar Rose has developed a number of facial-recognition technologies, including FaceCloud, a server-side solution to add facial recognition to any service. FaceLib is the company's mobile solution for iPhone and Android platforms, FaceCore is command-line tool, and Recognizr is a tool that combines facial recognition and augmented reality. Apple already has a couple of products, Aperture and iPhoto, that utilize facial recognition.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: To keep things simple (i.e., keep the "garbage in" to a minimum) and our future return expectations for Apple is based on 3 simple drivers: *Conservative Earnings Growth *Valuation Multiple Expansion *Dividend Growth Based on these inputs, I believe that it is reasonable to expect Apple to produce annual returns of 15-20% over the next 3 years.

Message.Title: Sprint record 2.2M iPhones 38% more new costumers
Message.Msg: Thursday, February 07, 2013, 07:51 am Sprint sold best-ever 2.2M iPhones in holiday quarter, 38% to new customers By AppleInsider Staff Sprint on Thursday announced its earnings for the fourth quarter of 2012, revealing it sold a best-ever 2.2 million iPhones, bringing its total 2012 sales to 6.6 million.Of the 2.2 million iPhones sold in the December quarter, 38 percent of those were to new customers. And 40 percent of the 6.6 million iPhones sold in all of 2012 were to customers new to the carrier. As of the fourth quarter, Sprint had sold more than 4 million 4G LTE smartphones, including Apple's iPhone 5, which debuted in September.Sprint sold a total of nearly 20 million smartphones in 2012. In the fourth quarter, 89 percent of postpaid handset sales were smartphones.Sprint's high-speed 4G LTE network, compatible with both the iPhone 5 and Apple's latest iPads, is now available in a total of 58 cities. The carrier expects to expand to nearly 170 more in the coming months, and construction has started in more than 450 cities.For the quarter, Sprint reported a net loss of $1.3 billion. Dan Hesse, the company's chief executive, attributed part of that loss to subsidies associated with Apple's iPhone, which he said is one of the company's "key investments." The 2.2 million iPhones sold by Sprint are an increase from the 1.5 million the carrier had activated over the last three consecutive quarters. The carrier had surpassed 1 million LTE smartphones just before the launch of the iPhone 5.

Message.Title: CNBC being controlled
Message.Msg: A terrible price is paid over a 43 trillion dollar lawsuit headline. Is it an inevitable fact of life that when we do the right thing and speak out against corruption and tyranny that there will be casualties? Apparently so. Does that mean we should cringe and hide when called upon to release the truth? No! Just a few days ago Kevin Krim, CNBC executive suffered the horrendous loss of two of his children to a brutal death just one day after the network’s broadcast of a top story that will be a game changer for the Obama administration and the corrupt banks they have been in collusion with. With the breaking news that top government officials in the Obama White House along with several major US banks, bankers involved in the wrongdoing, and their profiteering cronies that they will face a 43 trillion dollar lawsuit and criminal charges based upon racketeering and money laundering, came the sharp claws of reprisal. Kevin Krim’s children, 6 year old daughter Lucia, and 1 year old son Leo were found by his wife, Marina, in the bathtub dead. Suspect killer, the nanny, Yoselyn Ortega, who had apparently stabbed the two children and then herself was found laying near the bathtub with a kitchen knife close by in critical condition from apparent self inflicted wounds to her neck. Wife, Marina was found clutching her surviving 3 year old, Nessie, in hysterics after neighbors called police when hearing the sounds and screams of a struggle. Marina had returned home after taking Nessie to a swimming lesson. CNBC digital media executive Kevin Krim, who had been on a business trip, was met by authorities at the airport and was then escorted to the hospital. The 50 year old nanny was rushed to the ER under police custody. Both of the Krim’s children were pronounced dead on arrival, having succumbed to their wounds before the arrival of an ambulance. google the rest of the story....individuals at CNBC are afraid of this type of backlash is they report the truth about aapl.mlee &jc

And RIMM / BBRY's new BB10 phone is at best equal to Apple's old model IPHONE4 in performance, plus BBRY is not even able to deliver it to its U.S. Distributors till mid-March despite announcing it in late January. Both NOK and RIMM/BBRY continue to lose money, and don't appear to be coming back. Topic.Title: With a bit of luck, Einhorn's intervention may ignite the bounce.

Message.Msg: MarketWatch presented Goldman Sachs' top ten picks for upside potential in 2013 earlier today. It was nice to see two of my core holdings listed as #1 and #2 on the presentation and have two other of my positions in the top ten as well. Here are Goldman Sachs' top three picks for upside potential in 2013 profiled. #1 - Apple (AAPL) - No surprise here given the low valuation of this once beloved market darling. Goldman Sachs sees the shares climbing to $660 a share in 2013. 4 reasons AAPL is extremely cheap at $458 a share: The stock is selling at just 9x forward earnings, a deep discount to its five year average (18.2). The company has over $135B in net cash and marketable securities on its balance sheet. This is enough to buy Ford, Nike and Kimberley Clark and still have change left over to put in perspective. Apple's growth story is not over. It is expected to grow revenues in the mid-double digits for both FY2013 and FY2014 and the stock sports a minuscule five year projected PEG (.52). The company is generating over $40B of cash annually and the stock is selling at the bottom of its five year valuation range based on P/E, P/CF, P/B and P/S.

Message.Title: Understanding Einhorn and Apple
Message.Msg: David Einhorn is absolutely right, but its even better than that. What he is proposing will not materially change the value of the business, but it would transfer risk from common stockholders to preferred holders while at the same time forcing the market to recognize a more appropriate value in Apples stock. This is no different than what private equity guys do. It's just leveraging the balance sheet and extracting the cash up front while dumping the risk on debt holders (in the case of private equity they dump the risk on banks and bond holders in Apples case Einhorn is advocating we dump the risk of the business on preferred holders). He is 100% right. There would no problem finding 500 billion dollars of yield pigs to take on our risk while allowing us to immediately recognize the value in our common stock.

Message.Title: AAPL CEO facing multiple challenges - will he be able to manage?
Message.Msg: 1. Lack of innovation: AAPL used to be ahead of competition by at least a year, but lately it tries to catch up (Samsung offered bigger screen on smart phone first). Unless AAPL leapfrog everytime, high margins can't be justified. 2. Need of new products: iPad was last new product. It's time they have something new iWatch or iTV or whatever. But make sure it combines hardware and software. Lately, AAPL is becoming more hardware priented which is a low margin business (ask SONY). 3. Execute better: No more Mapgates or scratchgates (that messed up supplychain and increaseed costs). Got to stay on the top of things (Ckook needs to be more hands-on like Jobs). 4. Cash problem: Can't just keep accumulating cash (just added $23 bi just last quarter). Cash earning close to zero doesn't maximize shareholder value. Either distribute as dividend, or do aggressive buyback (at least 10%; last 1% buyback was pathetixc) or do acquisitions, or develop new products by hiring more people. Sitting on a bigger and bigger cash pile is unacceptable - put that cash to work to maximize the shareholder value. 5. Stop being so secret: AAPL needs to keep product plans secret for competitive reasons but being coy about financials leads to analyst making gusses and when AAPL fails to meet estimates, stock gets hurt. Either give more info so analyst can make better estimates or issue warning when you feel like you are not going to meet analyst estimates. Secrecy is a netrr loss for the company and shareholders. 6. Split the stock: It's harder for stock to go up even if earnings are OK - it's time to split the stock to broaden ownership. So far Cook has failed on every front. He will have to show rather soon that he can manage or otherwise he should lead the way to be replaced by someone who can lead, someone who is visionary, hands-on executioner, and ruthless at decimating competition via aggressive innovation (Cook is way too laidback).

Topic.Title: Understanding Einhorn and Apple

Message.Msg: i think it is a clever idea that he has proposed to cook yesterday. lets see if apple financial advisers can make a recommendation to the board on this matter. so far he is only asking shareholders to vote NO to the proxy on apples proposed abolishment of the preferred. here's a contrarian view: If Apple issued $50 billion of new preferred stock, this preferred stock would be "senior" to Apple's common stock--the stock that trades for about $450 a share these days. What that means is that, if Apple got liquidated tomorrow, the folks who owned the preferred stock would get $50 billion off the top before Apple's common shareholders got anything. If the market is behaving even remotely rationally, the market should therefore respond by knocking the value of Apple's common stock down by about $50 billion. In other words, if Apple issued $50 billion of this new class of preferred stock tonight, the price of Apple's common stock should open tomorrow at about $400 a share. Why? Because no matter how good a financial engineer you are, you can't just wave your magic wand and make something out of nothing. If Apple issues this stock tonight, the value of Apple's enterprise and assets will not change. All that will change is the form of ownership of, and claim on, these assets. And the folks who own the $50 billion of preferred stock will have a more senior claim on those assets than the folks who own the common stock. Einhorn may believe--and he may be right--that Apple's issuing preferred stock will befuddle mom and pop investors who won't take the time to understand that they now have a claim to less of Apple's assets than they did before. And Einhorn may hope that, as a result of this befuddlement, the market will misprice the preferred stock and common stock, thus allowing him to do what every financial engineer wants to do--appear to create something out of nothing. And, again, Einhorn may be right. He's brilliant. And anything is possible.

Message.Title: Understanding Apple and Einhorn Math
Message.Msg: Market Cap today is around 430 billion. Apple could issue the 4% preferreds today and get proceeds of 430 billion. It can take that 430 billion and pay it out as a one time dividend. So that's exactly a dividend equal to the share price today of 460 per share. You would essentially get all your money back today if you purchase today, but you still get to keep your shares. Now, what's left? Apple will still have 137 billion in cash, but now it has about 20 billion in annul preferred dividend payments to make. No problem, they have free cash flow that's roughly 30 to 33 billion to draw that from. Net, this leaves them with 13 billion retained for common shareholders. With a low multiple of 10 times we are looking at 130 billion in value in addition to 137 billion in cash. That's 260 billion or greater than 260 dollars per share of value for common stock holders in addition to the 460 dollars per share we were just paid out. Lets do this now.

Topic.Title: Einhorn Didn't Just Go Public, HE FILED SUIT, And, He Could Win...

Message.Msg: Well, yeah, but Einhorn can't legally force Apple to issue preferred, but he might have a shot at forcing them to drop the giveaway by the Board of the option to do so in the upcoming vote. Directors/management have great leeway and discretion in how to use corporate funds, forcing specific methods on them is a tough fight and likely a loser. But public pressure can and does move intransigent managements, and this is very, very public.

Message.Title: AAPL so called disapointing Q is the best Q ever reportedby tech companies in history 13 weeks those idiots don't get it
Message.Msg: Even after a quarter widely panned on Wall Street as ‘flat’ or ‘disappointing,’ Apple holds the top spot among the most profitable U.S. companies by a significant margin,” Kevin Bostic reports for AppleInsider. “The $13.1 billion in profit Apple posted for the first quarter of 2013 is the most profitable quarter for a tech company in history, just edging out the record $13.06 billion set in the first quarter of 2012 — also by Apple,” Bostic reports. “A comparison of Apple’s record quarter to those of the other most profitable companies in the United States shows Apple head and shoulders above its American peers.”Bostic reports, “Apple’s $13.1 billion in profit is 31 percent more than the $10 billion of its closest competitor, oil giant ExxonMobil… Apple earned more than twice the $6.4 billion of its nearest competitor, Redmond software giant Microsoft. Add in the $5.8 billion earned by IBM, and Apple still beats the total by nearly a billion dollars.

Message.Msg: When a large shareholder goes public and discloses his position to be so large even for him that invites sharks to squeeze him out. No shareholder in a $400 Billion company can force the board to act differently no matter who he is because he doesn't have that much influence. Einhorn sues, AAPl has $130 Billion and will fight back. The only way this board will do the right thing which is to disburse some hefty change to shareholders is if the stock tanks so much where execs and board member jobs and legacy are in stake. Hoarding cash is a bad idea as this reflects lack of management cpnfidence in the future of the company. As if they expect lay offs, cost savings and perhaps a severe drop in EPS. If this is not the case, then I agree the board ahs to diburse cash and get more aggressive. Enhorn sounded like us the little investor getting crushed. His comment about his grandmother was lame and non-relevant to this giant company. A quick flushout of shares leading to management change is what this company needs.

Topic.Title: They really need to split their stock 10:1, to attract a whole new class of retail investor.

Message.Msg: Lower stock price means a greater number of morons as stockholders (which is why Buffet has a high stock price, he wants to cut out the morons). With lower stock price you get more volatility probably, which makes options more expensive but also potentially more rewarding. Also, put options seem to work a lot better for me with a stock price that is higher, there is more room on the downside - not sure if that makes mathematical sense, but it is my experience anyway.

Message.Title: Einhorn is wrong.....
Message.Msg: Why in the world would ANY COMPANY want to build "in" a permanent cash boggie that they have to hit each quarter going forward? So TWO FED issues could Apples ability to move forward and KNOW, what they are up against after taking any course of action be it in line with Einhorn or not. Mr Einhorn's sentiment is not lost on me but, I do think there is alittle more to this cash LOCK than fearing a depression though no one, not even Mr Einhorn can tell any of us what impact this DumbamaCARE is going to have on all of us as consumers and tax payers. All IMHO of course............

Topic.Title: CREAMER, EINHORN, GS = USUAL SUSPECTS SPINING THEIR "TALES"

Message.Msg: Tiger Global owned 1.3 million shares of Apple /quotes/zigman/68270/quotes/nls/aapl AAPL +0.12% at the end of September. The drop in Apple's stock price over the last few months, including a plunge following its quarterly report, has left it at 10 times trailing earnings. The sell-side has been reducing its targets for the company but still expects moderately high earnings growth rates, and as a result the forward P/E is 9 and the five-year PEG ratio is 0.7. We would place ourselves between analyst consensus and current market sentiment: analyst expectations are too high, but the company will likely grow its earnings enough to prove undervalued. Apple was the most popular stock among hedge funds for the third quarter of 2012

Message.Title: Funny how a bad choice can yield good results...
Message.Msg: I normally bail out of options before eod on AAPL but last night forgetting it was ex-dividend, I carried some ill-timed 455 weeklies (this week) that I bought too high mid-afternoon over to today. Realizing my error, it was a sleepless night since I was convinced that we would open lower this AM with the divy bundled and I had put a significant contract count. So I beat myself up all night (woe is me, how could I have been so careless, etc.) and finally looked at premarket this morning about 8:00AM to find a present in my stocking. So I dropped in a sell with a very tight trailing stop at the open and suddenly I looked like a genius (at least to my wife). I was very fortunate. And blessed. This kind of mistake certainly deepened my prayer life. I'm grateful. Hope you all have had some success today as well. Lots of trading opportunity there today. GLTA.

Message.Title: Apple's New Maps App
Message.Msg: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) received some of the highest levels of criticism to its new maps app, first launched last September, in its rapidly growing market of Japan. And it appears the company has chosen the country to launch the first of its big improvements to its native navigation program. On Wednesday, Apple released the first beta version of its operating system iOS 6.1.1 in Japan with a host of changes to the maps application. In a note to developers accompanying the Japan release, Apple said the iOS 6.1.1 beta 1 included improved pronunciation of roads, optimized directions to more strongly prefer highways over narrower roads, indications for upcoming toll roads, added labels for junctions, interchanges, and intersections, and added indicators for transit station buildings, subway lines, and traffic lights. It also announced that all freeways would now be in the color green and also updated icons for location categories, including fire stations, hospitals, and post offices. During the worldwide public release of the iOS 6.1 version of its mobile operating system last month, Apple had also announced a new Search API that would allow developers to query its maps servers to receive point-of-interest and location data.

Topic.Title: Einhorn Didn't Just Go Public, HE FILED SUIT, And, He Could Win...

Message.Msg: If u read the proposal 2 u will see that it states .. That the company will not be able to issue stock without share holder approval ..another words they can still issue but not independent of shareholders apptoval. Whats wrong with that.... I dont get what the pfoblem is! This a paste and copy from the proxy Elimination of “Blank Check” Preferred Stock The Company’s existing Articles permit the Board to issue shares of preferred stock having voting, conversion and other rights to be determined by the Board in its sole discretion. This is referred to as “blank check” preferred stock because it does not require shareholder approval. The Company has not issued shares of preferred stock since 1997, when it issued 150,000 shares of Series A Non-Voting Convertible Preferred Stock. Those shares were redeemed in full shortly thereafter. The Board does not intend to issue preferred stock in the future and believes that it is appropriate to eliminate this provision from the Articles. If the proposed amendment of the Articles is approved by the Company’s shareholders, any future issuances of preferred stock would require shareholder approval.

Message.Title: Whats Wrong With Oppenheimer? Why Is He So Phucked Up?
Message.Msg: "Reuters reports Thursday afternoon that Einhorn "chatted" with Apple CEO Tim Cook on Wednesday and that Cook was receptive to his proposals. Though Apple considered it for a while, the company rejected Einhorn's proposal on keeping the preferred shares in Apple's charter. Those talks had been with CFO Peter Oppenheimer, Einhorn noted. Cook wasn't familiar with Einhorn's previous conversations with Oppenheimer, Einhorn noted, nor whom Oppenheimer's advisors were. Einhorn said he was "surprised" by that.

Message.Title: 1/4 information workers wants an iPad 1/3 want iPhone MSFT no thanks
Message.Msg: Thursday, February 07, 2013, 02:42 pm Report: 1 in 4 information workers want Apple iPad for work, 1 in 3 want iPhone By Kevin Bostic Apple's best-selling iPad and iPhone continue to thrive in the consumer sector, but a new report indicates that iOS is positioned to challenge Microsoft in the enterprise segment as well. Forrester's 2013 Mobile Workforce Adoption Trends looked at work habits and desired technologies among 9,766 global information workers. Forrester says "anytime, anywhere information workers" that use three or more devices now constitute 29 percent of the global workforce, up from 23 percent in 2011. Forrester's analysis found that 21 percent of respondents were using a tablet at least weekly for work. Forty-eight percent were using a smartphone at least weekly for work.Among respondents using tablets for work, 58 percent relied on an iPad, more than twice the number using Android tablets and more than five times the number using Windows tablets. iOS was nearly even with Android among workers counting smartphones among their primary work devices; Android had 37 percent of respondents, while iOS had 34 percent. The BlackBerry platform, once nearly synonymous with mobile productivity, held a 15 percent share among respondents. Apple's future in the enterprise sector looks brighter when it comes to the devices respondents want for their next work smartphones or tablets. While 16 percent of respondents currently use an iPhone, 33 percent said they wanted an iPhone for their next work smartphone, as big a percentage as Android and Windows Phone combined. The tablet segment is also promising for Apple. Twenty-six percent of respondents want an iPad for their next work tablet, more than twice the percentage that want an Android-powered device. The enterprise tablet sector, though, also holds promise for Microsoft's Windows platform, as 32 percent of respondents said they would prefer a Windows tablet for their next device.

Message.Title: Why Is This Untested Management Team Against The Eienhorn Savior Plan?
Message.Msg: "We believe our suggestion of distributing perpetual preferred stock, while innovative, is also quite simple. Apple could distribute high-yielding, tax efficient preferred stock to existing shareholders at no cost. This new type of easily tradable preferred security would allow Apple to take advantage of the market’s appetite for yield while preserving future operating and strategic flexibility. Importantly, we believe this strategy would require no immediate use of cash other than the ongoing dividend, and would not pose any maturity, re-financing, balance sheet, or default risk. For example, Apple could initially distribute to existing shareholders $50 billion of perpetual preferred stock, with a 4% annual cash dividend paid quarterly at preferential tax rates. Once a trading market is established and the market recognizes the attractiveness of a highly liquid, steady yielding instrument from an issuer backed by Apple’s unmatched balance sheet and valuable franchise, the Board could evaluate unlocking additional value by distributing additional perpetual preferred stock to existing shareholders. With this conservative action, Greenlight believes the Board could unlock hundreds of billions of dollars of latent shareholder value. Assuming Apple retains its price to earnings multiple of 10x and the preferred stock yields 4%, our calculations show that every $50 billion of perpetual preferred stock that Apple distributes would unlock about $30 billion, or $32 per share in value. Greenlight believes that Apple has the capacity to ultimately distribute several hundred billion dollars of preferred, which would unlock hundreds of dollars of value per share. Further, Greenlight believes additional value may be realized when Apple’s price to earnings multiple expands, as the market appreciates a more shareholder friendly capital allocation policy."

Topic.Title: Why Is This Untested Management Team Against The Eienhorn Savior Plan?

Message.Msg: "Like Miller, Einhorn is basically making the case for Apple paying out future free cash flow – this is almost a separate issue from what to do the current enormous cash pile. A year from now, Apple’s cash position could be pushing $200 billion. That’s simply ridiculous, particularly given the company’s historical aversion to large acquisitions. The company has enough cash to buy literally any other company in the technology business; it could buy Facebook for $70 billion and still have plenty leftover to buy, say, Twitter, Dell, RIMM and Nokia. But as noted, Apple historically just doesn’t do transformative acquisitions, and they aren’t going to buy any of those companies. With the cash position now about 30% of market cap, and generating little return, there’s a case to be made that Apple’s giant cash security blanket is in fact weighing on the company’s valuation. They have more than enough cash for a rainy day; they have enough cash for the great flood. The cash, rather than a strategic advantage, is becoming a burden. Time for Apple to act."

Message.Title: Bernstein Analyst Toni Sacconaghi Apple Should Sell Debt And Raise Dividend To 4%
Message.Msg: "There is a widespread belief that Apple does not need to accumulate more cash and should be more aggressive in returning cash," Sanford C. Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi told CNBC's "Squawk on the Street" on Thursday. Earlier on CNBC, Greenlight Capital's David Einhorn defended his proposal for Apple to offer current shareholders perpetual preferred stock to deliver value. He is also filing suit against Apple over a proposal to eliminate preferred stock. Sacconaghi said, "The broader issue Mr. Einhorn is bringing to the table, and one esteemed investor Bill Miller raised yesterday, is that investors are dissatisfied with Apple's capital allocation policy, specifically returning cash." But investors and analysts are divided on exactly how Apple should proceed. "I believe that Apple should look to take on debt at very low rate and dramatically increase its dividend," Sacconaghi said. "Others believe that Apple should return more cash through buybacks." He added, "The fact is for a company to have $137 billion and to be adding $40 billion a year is destroying economic value for shareholders." About $85 billion of the Apple cash pile is overseas, so any major cash return would likely mean it will have to pay taxes on that cash — something Apple appears reluctant to do, Sacconaghi said. But a major change in capital allocation policies could be what finally turns around Apple's share price, Sacconaghi said, telling CNBC a 15 percent dividend hike wouldn't be enough. "I think really to get value investors, who are the constituent Apple needs to tap into to own the stock to really move it, you need the dividend in the high 3 percent range," the analyst said. "Ideally, you want a 4-percent-plus dividend. That will really get the stock moving."

Message.Title: Read proposal 2... Apple never wanted to block preferred stock.. They only offered shareholder approval for it !
Message.Msg: Elimination of “Blank Check” Preferred Stock The Company’s existing Articles permit the Board to issue shares of preferred stock having voting, conversion and other rights to be determined by the Board in its sole discretion. This is referred to as “blank check” preferred stock because it does not require shareholder approval. The Company has not issued shares of preferred stock since 1997, when it issued 150,000 shares of Series A Non-Voting Convertible Preferred Stock. Those shares were redeemed in full shortly thereafter. The Board does not intend to issue preferred stock in the future and believes that it is appropriate to eliminate this provision from the Articles. If the proposed amendment of the Articles is approved by the Company’s shareholders, any future issuances of preferred stock would require shareholder approval.

Message.Title: Statment by AAPL considering GreenLight proposal- read
Message.Msg: By early last year, Apple’s cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years. As of next week we will have executed $10 billion of that plan. We find ourselves in the fortunate position of continuing to generate large amounts of cash, including $23 billion in cash flow from operations in the last quarter alone. Apple’s management team and Board of Directors have been in active discussions about returning additional cash to shareholders. As part of our review, we will thoroughly evaluate Greenlight Capital’s current proposal to issue some form of preferred stock. We welcome Greenlight’s views and the views of all of our shareholders. As a part of our efforts to further enhance corporate governance and serve our shareholders’ best interests, Proposal #2 in our proxy includes some recommended changes to our articles of incorporation. These changes were recommended independently of Greenlight’s proposal and would not preclude Apple from adopting their concept. Contrary to Greenlight’s statements, adoption of Proposal #2 would not prevent the issuance of preferred stock. Currently, Apple’s articles of incorporation provide for the issuance of “blank check” preferred stock by the Board of Directors without shareholder approval. If Proposal #2 is adopted, our shareholders would have the right to approve the issuance of preferred stock. As such, Proposal #2 has the support of many of our shareholders. We remain committed to having an ongoing dialogue with our shareholders to get perspectives around return of capital and driving shareholder value.

With $137 Billion in cash they can buy any other technical company. They could just buy Samsung with pocket change. Don't kid yourselves. These guys are still in charge of the smartphone and pad world.

Message.Title: This is why I suggested setting conditional buy limit order at $463.25 an hour ago.
Message.Msg: Had you just entered a buy limit order at $463.25 ehrn AAPL was only 458, it would have filled at 458. However, there was no confirmatiion of trend reversal unless AAPL was able to trade and stay above its open price of $463.25. So setting a conditional buy limit order at $463.25, only if, last trade was avove $463.25 meant your broker was not going to fill your order at $463.25 UNLESS the LAST TRADE was above $463.25. You had to let the market prove someone else wanted it at higher than its open on a day like today. Once $463.25 was filled by someone else, your trigger was set, and once it traded agan at $463.25, which it will undoubtedly do, then you got the open price.

Topic.Title: IDIOTS...this is last day before dividend, that is why its up, not apple einhorn

Message.Msg: today is EX-DIV day, by DEFINITION its the day AFTER the last day you are entitled to RECEIVE the DIVIDEND PLEASE SHAPE UP AND HUMBLE DOWN Ex-Dividend Date A stock’s ex-dividend date is the first day an owner can sell the stock without losing the rights to its upcoming dividend. Obviously, it’s also the first day a buyer who purchases the stock will not receive that same dividend. A good way to remember how the ex-dividend date works is to think of it as a synonym for “without dividend.” A stock trading on or after its ex-dividend date is trading without its dividend.

Topic.Title: IDIOTS...this is last day before dividend, that is why its up, not apple einhorn

Message.Msg: If you sell before the ex-dividend date you will not receive a dividend from the company. The ex-dividend date is the date that the company has designated as the first day of trading in which the shares trade without the right to the dividend. If you sell your shares on or after this date, you will still receive the dividend.

Message.Title: Daily Stock Buyback Plan!!
Message.Msg: Apple doesn't need a new preferred stock. It can return more profits to investors in a tax advantaged way by instituting a daily stock buyback plan. Every trading day Apple would buy $100M of AAPL in the market at a constant rate. Its a kind of dollar cost averaging of profits back to shareholders. When the stock is low, more shares are purchased, when the stock is high, fewer shares are purchased. All profits are taxed as capital gains. Its a simple plan to execute and helps everyone!

Message.Title: Done Deal Now $23+ Billion For New Value Shareholder Base @ Feb 27th Annual Meeting
Message.Msg: By early last year, Apple's (Nasdaq: AAPL) cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years. As of next week we will have executed $10 billion of that plan. We find ourselves in the fortunate position of continuing to generate large amounts of cash, including $23 billion in cash flow from operations in the last quarter alone.

Topic.Title: Did you notice in AAPL's press release, they said.....

Message.Msg: Here is the press release Statement by Apple CUPERTINO, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--By early last year, Apple’s cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years. As of next week we will have executed $10 billion of that plan. We find ourselves in the fortunate position of continuing to generate large amounts of cash, including $23 billion in cash flow from operations in the last quarter alone. Apple’s management team and Board of Directors have been in active discussions about returning additional cash to shareholders. As part of our review, we will thoroughly evaluate Greenlight Capital’s current proposal to issue some form of preferred stock. We welcome Greenlight’s views and the views of all of our shareholders. As a part of our efforts to further enhance corporate governance and serve our shareholders’ best interests, Proposal #2 in our proxy includes some recommended changes to our articles of incorporation. These changes were recommended independently of Greenlight’s proposal and would not preclude Apple from adopting their concept. Contrary to Greenlight’s statements, adoption of Proposal #2 would not prevent the issuance of preferred stock. Currently, Apple’s articles of incorporation provide for the issuance of “blank check” preferred stock by the Board of Directors without shareholder approval. If Proposal #2 is adopted, our shareholders would have the right to approve the issuance of preferred stock. As such, Proposal #2 has the support of many of our shareholders. We remain committed to having an ongoing dialogue with our shareholders to get perspectives around return of capital and driving shareholder value.

Message.Title: Apple stuck. Only 43B in USA. 2x dividend and it's gone in 3 to 4 years
Message.Msg: Apple knows it is stuck because cash is only 43B in the USA. If they want to double the dividend it will deplete 10B to 12B of this per year. This means in about 3 to 4 years they will not have any US based cash left. Forced to bring home overseas cash they take a 35% hit on it which they won't do. They don't want to take on debt and lose another 1% to 3% on the net income due to interest payments just to pay whining shareholders. Even if they brought home the 93B overseas it gets slashed to about 60B. At 20/yr dividend (4%) they would chew through this in just a few years. Apple is in a no win situation now that earnings have stalled to 0% YOY. Now just a value stock that is stuck paying a sub value dividend that they cannot raise enough without ripping through cash. Unless repatriation tax laws change apple is in big trouble when it come to unlocking any value. Overseas cash is basically in an untouchable vault which it will remain in until maybe someday they need it to pay the bills if cash starts burning. Einhorn won't get anything from Apple. They may split the proposal but it ends there. Apple knows it is in a corner and cannot double the dividend, take on huge debt or do a mass buyback. If they do the cash they hoard and so fear losing will get to uncomfortable levels for them.

Topic.Title: Apple stuck. Only 43B in USA. 2x dividend and it's gone in 3 to 4 years

Message.Msg: You are not entirely right here. Yes they can take a foreign tax credit. However only to the extent they paid taxes overseas. Thanks to the double dutch irish sandwich tax trick they only paid 2% overseas. That means 33% tax hit if they bring it over. Yes when they report EPS it is GAAP accounted for BUT that does not change what cash is in the bank. I look at cash in the bank and cash flow which is what they would use to pay dividend or do buyback. So if they want to bring that money back they lose 1/3 of the actual cash. Yes it won't change reported EPS but the real dollars in the bank are slashed. My post above stands. Do your research if you do not believe or understand me. You must know what your are buying

Topic.Title: Apple Dividend - Just curious how long do I have to keep apple

Message.Msg: A dividend-paying stock's ex-dividend date is very important to investors. In a nutshell, if you buy a dividend stock before the ex-dividend date, then you will receive the next upcoming dividend payment. If you purchase the stock on or after the ex-dividend date, you will not receive the dividend. The converse of this rule also holds true -- if you sell a stock before the ex-dividend date, you will not receive the dividend, but if you sell on or after the ex-dividend date, you will.

Topic.Title: AAPL will quickly and easily go to 550

Message.Msg: Yes! Finally! Someone who truly understands fiances! Or did you mean finance? No, you must have meant fiances... because you clearly know nothing about finance. Dividends are not a means to affect dramatic and sustained share price growth. They typically provide a short-term improvement that roughly corresponds to the dividend increase itself... and does so at a price (namely FCF impairment incurred by the company in paying the dividend). If paying a dividend was truly a catalyst for share price, Apple would not be trading for less now than before it started paying a dividend. True share price recovery will come from incremental performance and improved investor sentiment.

Topic.Title: Last Chance for Manic Depressive shorts to end it all

Message.Msg: There's nothing wrong with Shorts, who put their money where their mouths are. In fact I wish there were more people brave enough to short AAPL stock. The problem is Market Manipulators like CNBC and Kass, who tell you to buy the stock when they want to sell their position, and try and foment panic selling when they want to buy it. Case in point Weds. around noon-time Kass announced he'd bought Apple stock Monday in the $440s and sold by Weds. morning when it popped over $460. Then an article appeared on MANIPULATIVE CNBC ABOUT HOW KASS WAS no LONGER LONG AAPL, AND SAID IT WAS TOO HIGH PRICED TO BUY BACK IN. Lo and behold, after-hours, CNBC puts on some Vanity Fair ditz who claims to know that AAPL stock would drop to $200 (within hours after KASS connected to CNBC sold his position in AAPL). Kass is always saying negative things about AAPL when he wants to buy in cheaper, and vice versa. These Hedge Fund operators should not be allowed to use the press to engage in deliberate manipulation of Mom and Pop investors.

Message.Msg: PROPOSAL NO. 2 Amendment of Articles of Incorporation The Company's shareholders are being asked to approve the amendment of the Restated Articles of Incorporation (the "Articles"). If approved, the amendment would: 1. eliminate certain language relating to the term of office of directors in order to facilitate the adoption of majority voting for the election of directors; 2. eliminate "blank check" preferred stock; 3. establish a par value for the Company's common stock of $0.00001 per share; and 4. make other conforming changes as set forth in the text of the amendment below, including eliminating provisions in the Articles relating to preferred stock of the Company.

Message.Title: Einhorn had no business investing in a tech name like Apple
Message.Msg: Einhorn had no business investing in a tech name like Apple, much less making it his #1 position. I love it when these value/activist guys think they know it all and venture into tech thinking they can apply the same techniques as they would for an "old economy" name. Gee, the stock is cheap so it must be a good investment. Tech names do NOT have hard assets. They typically do not own factories, machinery, or real estate. They live and die by the ever changing product cycle. Miss one and they might never recover. So what happened here is that Einhorn was late in jumping on the Apple bandwagon and late getting off so now he's losing a lot of money on the position and trying to stir the pot. Next time Einhorn should at least get some experts to help him out. Any%2

It will technically help with several things; 1. the cash does not have to be repatriated (even though the tax issue is NOT a big problem) 2. using the fantastic balance sheet and cash flow of Apple (safer than US Gov!) would be a great way to have safe income - I.e.; since they can not do anything better with it - then let share holders get some interest! (It's THEIR money after all!). The simpler alternative would be some SOLID stock buy back (not just a few billion here and there). - That would however mean repatriation of money - but again; simple notes(bonds) could be issued paying only 1% interest in the USA - again avoiding the tax issue all together.

Topic.Title: issue of preferred stock

Message.Msg: Einhorn proposes that AAPL issue $50 billion of preferred stock that pays a 4% dividend. This proposal has been rebuffed by AAPL in the past. Einhorn suggests that the issuance of preferred stock will increase the value of AAPL stock. How? Highly unlikely AAPL will follow this suggestion BUT now the company will be pressured to return more money to shareholders. This will be a hot issue at the upcoming shareholders meeting on February 27, 2013. Any up move to AAPL stock will be temporary since Wall Street is convinced that AAPL is facing eroding margins and declining profits.

Message.Title: STATEMENT BY APPLE.
Message.Msg: CUPERTINO, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- By early last year, Apple’s cash balance had built to a point beyond what we needed to run our business and maintain flexibility to take advantage of strategic opportunities, so we announced a plan to return $45 billion to shareholders over three years. As of next week we will have executed $10 billion of that plan. We find ourselves in the fortunate position of continuing to generate large amounts of cash, including $23 billion in cash flow from operations in the last quarter alone. Apple’s management team and Board of Directors have been in active discussions about returning additional cash to shareholders. As part of our review, we will thoroughly evaluate Greenlight Capital’s current proposal to issue some form of preferred stock. We welcome Greenlight’s views and the views of all of our shareholders. As a part of our efforts to further enhance corporate governance and serve our shareholders’ best interests, Proposal #2 in our proxy includes some recommended changes to our articles of incorporation. These changes were recommended independently of Greenlight’s proposal and would not preclude Apple from adopting their concept. Contrary to Greenlight’s statements, adoption of Proposal #2 would not prevent the issuance of preferred stock. Currently, Apple’s articles of incorporation provide for the issuance of “blank check” preferred stock by the Board of Directors without shareholder approval. If Proposal #2 is adopted, our shareholders would have the right to approve the issuance of preferred stock. As such, Proposal #2 has the support of many of our shareholders. We remain committed to having an ongoing dialogue with our shareholders to get perspectives around return of capital and driving shareholder value.

Topic.Title: aapl should issue 75 billion in debt at 2.2%, non callable 10 yr

Message.Msg: Why non-callable? Are callable bonds that much higher interest rate? I agree with you that debt is very cheap now, and Apple stock is the best investment, so taking on debt to buy back shares makes a lot of sense. Message.Title: Whatever happened to BOHICA BOB, Perennial Short in Apple
Message.Msg: Bohica Bob from Omaha, had been posting for a half year about impending market crash and how Apple stock was a goner, starting when Apple was in low to mid $300s back in summer 2011. Last I saw his posts exhorting people to Short Apple Stock in Feb. 2012, he also said GO LONG TVIX as a "paired trade". Apple shot up like crazy the first half of 2012, and TVIX plummeted 90%. After he shorted Apple and it soon went up $50, and he went Long TVIX and one day it plunged over 50% (down over 90% last year) we never heard from Bohica Bob again. Too bad he couldn't get on CNBC and shill his positions to manipulate the public like KASS..etc.
